newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Illovo, Tongaat and unions to meet.
newsitem.headline: Illovo, Tongaat and unions to meet.

text.p: Five unions representing 4,000 striking South African sugar workers, who have halted milling and refining operations for six days, will hold talks with employers on Monday afternoon, a union spokesman said.
Workers went on strike at midnight on Tuesday to back demands for a 20 percent wage increase across the board. Illovo Sugar Ltd and Tongaat-Hulett Ltd have offered 10.5 percent.
Talks are to be held in Durban on Monday afternoon and the unions are hopeful the deadlock could be reolved, Food and Allied Workers' Union spokesman Zwile Zulu said.
"We are going to meet the employers this afternoon (Monday), and we hope that we are going to resolve this wage dispute today," Zulu told Reuters.
Although the official spokesman representing Illovo and Tongaat could not be reached for comment, his office confirmed the meeting would be taking place.
The strike has come in the middle of the harvesting season which began in April and ends in December.
The industry has predicted a record harvest this year of an estimated 2.5 million tonnes.
A sugar industry source said earlier if the strike ran into weeks the harvest could be affected, but if it was resolved quickly the loss in production could be made up in what remained of the season.
